race.name: Big Horn Gravel
race.tagline: Wyoming wilderness gravel. Where the mountains meet the high plains.

climate.description: August brings warm days, cool mornings, and the ever-present Wyoming wind

terrain.primary: Big Horn Mountain foothills meeting high plains
terrain.surface: Variable gravel—maintained county roads to rougher forest service roads

history.origin_story: Created to showcase the Big Horn Mountain region's incredible gravel roads and wild landscapes. Part of Wyoming's growing gravel scene.
notable_moments: Positioned as true backcountry adventure racing
Growing reputation for authentic Western experience
history.reputation: True Wyoming adventure. Remote, wild, and utterly beautiful.

course_description.character: Big sky, big views, big wind. Classic high-plains gravel with mountain backdrop.

suffering_zones.label: Wind Games Begin
suffering_zones.desc: Wyoming's famous wind starts testing your patience.

suffering_zones.label: Mountain Shadows
suffering_zones.desc: The Big Horns loom. You're not done yet.

course_description.signature_challenge: The wind. Wyoming wind is relentless and unpredictable. Headwind miles feel twice as long. The isolation amplifies everything.

prestige.explanation: Regional race without national recognition—yet. As the event matures and word spreads, this could grow. Right now it's a hidden gem.

length.explanation: 100 miles in remote Wyoming terrain is serious. The combination of distance, wind, and isolation creates a proper challenge.

technicality.explanation: Variable gravel quality but nothing overly technical. The challenge is duration and conditions, not bike handling.

elevation.explanation: 8,000 feet of climbing is meaningful, especially combined with altitude and wind. The terrain is rolling rather than steep.

climate.explanation: August Wyoming is generally pleasant for riding, but wind is ever-present. Prepare for exposure and temperature swings.

altitude.explanation: Racing at 4,000-6,000+ feet. Not extreme but noticeable for sea-level riders. Arrive a day or two early.

adventure.explanation: This is genuine Wyoming wilderness. Big Horn Mountains, open range, cowboy country. Few gravel races offer this level of authenticity.

biased_opinion.summary: Big Horn Gravel delivers what many big races have lost: genuine adventure in actual wilderness. No crowds, no chaos, just you and the Wyoming landscape. If you want to feel small against something vast, this is your race.
strengths: Authenticity: Real Wyoming, real remoteness, real adventure.
The scenery: Big Horn Mountains + high plains = stunning.
Low crowds: Intimate race with genuine community.
weaknesses: Obscurity: Not a resume race. Few people know it.
Logistics: Sheridan is remote. Plan your travel carefully.
The wind: Wyoming wind can make or break your day.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: For adventure seekers who want gravel racing in actual wilderness, Big Horn delivers. Not for those chasing prestige or Instagram clout.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: Sheridan, Wyoming is not a cycling destination. You're going specifically for this race into genuine backcountry. That's the beauty and the challenge.
consequences: Travel logistics require effort. Fly into Billings (2+ hours) or Denver (5+ hours).
Limited accommodation. Book early in Sheridan.
Self-sufficiency matters. Remote sections mean real consequences for mechanicals.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is backcountry adventure racing. The infrastructure is minimal by design. Come prepared, mentally and physically, for genuine challenge.

final_verdict.one_liner: True Wyoming wilderness gravel—where prestige takes a backseat to genuine adventure.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you value authentic backcountry experience over recognition. Yes if you want to feel small against something big. Not if you need crowds and clout.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Western gravel with more infrastructure: SBT GRVL or Crusher. If you want similar intimacy: other regional races in less traveled areas.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Sheridan has limited hotels. Book 2+ months ahead. Consider camping or VRBO.
logistics.food: Small-town dining. Don't expect big-city options.
logistics.parking: Start area parking is generally manageable.

seo.meta_description: Big Horn Gravel Sheridan guide: 100-mile gravel race. Get training plans & course breakdown.
